page.title: 08Population of Horton
page.content:
The population of the village is much the same now as it was 120 years ago. The 1870 census shows a steep rise in population due to the presence of workers building the Settle-Carlisle Railway, who were housed in shanty towns close to their work.
The opening of Horton Quarry in 1887 also led to a rise in population. After 1960, when farming and quarrying became increasingly mechanised the population declined to its pre-1870 level. The village is a stable community with a balanced spread of age groups. Outwardly there is no big gulf between rich and poor; nor are strong class differences apparent. Twenty years ago most people belonged to families which went back for 100 years or more. New-comers are moving in but they are still a minority.
